report_title: Gold & Silver Ore Mining in the US
executive_summary: The Gold and Silver Ore Mining industry explores and develops land to extract precious metals for sale in concentrate, dore and bullion form. Revenue is largely a function of mine output and the world prices of gold and silver. Despite an increase in revenue in 2020 amid the breakout of the COVID-19 pandemic heightening demand for precious metals, overall industry revenue has been on the decline due to reduced mine output from resource depletion and lower grades. Industry revenue is projected to have decreased at a CAGR of 0.6% to $11.1 billion over the five years to 2024, with a 2.7% drop in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Miners Benefit as the World Prices of Gold and Silver Rise
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Gold and silver mining companies sell their precious metals in the spot market where the prices of these commodities are constantly changing. Miners earn more revenue and profit when they sell their precious metals at higher prices. The world prices of gold and silver have been on the rise over the past five years as demand has outpaced supply.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Production of Gold and Silver is in a Long-Term Decline
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The United States produces half the quantity of gold and silver now that it did in 2000. The United States produced 170.0 metric tons of gold and 1,000.0 tons of silver in 2023 (latest data available). Production is down from 353.0 metric tons of gold and 1,980.0 metric tons of silver in 2000.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Gold and silver mining companies in the United States have had trouble
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Gold and silver mining companies in the United States have had trouble maintaining production due to natural resource depletion along with recent mine closures.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Nevada and Alaska continue to dominate the industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Nevada and Alaska continue to dominate the industry, with Nevada producing over 70.0% of the country's gold, followed by Alaska, and Alaska producing around half of the country's silver, followed by Nevada.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Demand for Luxury Goods Slumps During a Recession
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The single-largest use of gold and silver is for jewelry fabrication. Spending on luxury goods, including gold and silver watches, necklaces, rings and bracelets, is typically first to be cut by consumers when the economy is turbulent.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consumer Confidence and Interest Rates Will Have an Impact
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the coming years, the price of gold and silver are set to fall, driving down industry revenue. Precious metals like gold and silver continue to be investment choices to curtail risk in other asset classes such as equities, bonds, real estate, and cash. Demand will therefore fluctuate with investor uncertainty in the coming years.

Real interest rates, which are the interest rates that investors earn after accounting for inflation, have an inverse relationship with the world prices of gold and silver. As such, when the Federal Reserve undertakes efforts to combat inflation by increasing interest rates, traditional assets become more appealing compared to precious metals. The opportunity cost of holding gold and silver rises with interest rates.

As a consequence of tight labor market conditions, the mining industry is grappling with a shortage of workers, which escalates wage costs and squeezes profitability. This dynamic is expected to continue into the next five years.

The gold and silver mining industry is enduring strong pressure to improve environmental responsibility. There is an accelerating trend towards environmentally friendly mining equipment, and practices to reduce environmental damage.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry mine gold and silver-bearing ores. Mining activities include the development of mine sites and the on-site processing of ore into a concentrate or bullion. Companies typically retain ownership of the semiprocessed gold or silver products and pay for further refining on a toll-charge basis.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level high - steady

key_trends: The United States produces nearly half the quantity of gold and silver that it did in 2000. Domestic gold and silver exploration activity has dropped since the new millennium and companies have had difficulties successfully replacing annual production with new reserves.
Real interest rates are negatively correlated with the price of gold. Fed rate hikes pose a threat to the industry as the opportunity cost of holding precious metals increases.

The world prices of gold and silver are extremely volatile and highly dependent on investor and consumer sentiment. Revenue and profit can fluctuate significantly based on the underlying prices companies receive for their metals.

Mining companies are under significant pressure from investors and stakeholders to improve mineral recovery processes and reduce their overall environmental impact. The implementation of sustainable practices and advanced technology is crucial in addressing these concerns.
The key uses for gold and silver are as an investment vehicle and as a material to fabricate jewelry. Demand from investors picked up during the COVID-19 pandemic, while demand from jewelers slumped.

The Federal Reserve has increased interest rates to multi-decade highs to combat rampant inflation. Although gold and silver are good hedges against inflation, higher interest rates typically put pressure on precious metal prices.

Nevada accounts for about 73.0% of all gold produced in the United States. Most of this production is controlled by the Nevada Gold Mines joint venture between Barrick (61.5% ownership) and Newmont (38.5%).

Alaska is the largest producer of silver in the United States, accounting for more than one-half of total silver production. Alaska's Greens Creek and Red Dog mines lead the United States in silver production.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Gold and silver are frequently used in jewelry fabrication, as these metals are valuable, appealing to consumers and easy to work with.
Central banks regularly hold gold since it is regarded as the ultimate asset in an emergency. The value of gold often appreciates during financial uncertainty.
Individual investors as well as multinational investment institutions use precious metals as a store of value and hedge against inflation.
Gold and silver coins are often purchased for investment purposes, including as a store of value and a hedge against inflation.
Gold and silver are used in conductive adhesives, fuses and switches in electronic equipment due to their excellent electrical and thermal conducting properties.
Silver and gold have several other miscellaneous uses, including in healthcare and photography.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Economic Turbulence and Metal Prices Impact Demand
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for gold and silver jewelry and other luxury goods were extremely volatile throughout the COVID-19 pandemic due to sharp changes in economic uncertainty.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Retail and Institutional Investors Snap Up Precious Metals
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Individual investors as well as multinational investment institutions use precious metals as a store of value and hedge against inflation.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Central Banks Hold Gold as a Store of Value and for Financial Stability
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Central banks regularly hold gold since it is regarded as the ultimate asset in an emergency. The value of gold often appreciates during financial uncertainty.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Coins, Medals and Imitation Coins Make Up a Steady Revenue Stream
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Gold and silver coins are often purchased for investment purposes, including as a store of value and a hedge against inflation.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Demand from Electronic Equipment Manufacturers is Poised to Rise
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Electronic and electronic markets represent an important source of demand for gold and silver due to their excellent electrical and thermal conducting properties.

international_trade_points.trade_title: United States production is sufficient to cover domestic demand
international_trade_points.trade_description: The United States imports very little unrefined gold and silver. Imports have been valued at less than $5.0 million in recent years.
Imports of gold and silver jumped to $25.0 million in 2020 as investors piled into the safe-haven assets to hedge against economic uncertainty and rising inflation.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Canada and Mexico are the Leading Sources of Imports
international_trade_points.trade_description: In most years, the primary source of gold and silver imports is Canada. There are several large gold mines near the border and major players headquartered in Canada.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Exports Represent an Extremely Small Source of Revenue
international_trade_points.trade_description: International sales of unrefined gold and silver consistently represent less than 5.0% of revenue for the industry.

international_trade_points.trade_title: New Markets for Exports Have Appeared in Recent Years
international_trade_points.trade_description: The United States looks to strengthen relations with strategic nations like Japan and Taiwan by trading precious commodities with these countries.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has the highest percentage of both establishments and population, around 30-35%.
The West region has the second-highest percentage of establishments, around 20%, but a relatively lower percentage of population, around 10-15%.
Nevada is home to many of the world's largest gold mines and is responsible for 73.0% of total US gold production.
Alaska produces more silver than any other state in the United States, accounting for nearly one-half of all silver output.
The Rocky Mountains is the third-most concentrated region for gold and silver mining locations.
The Plains region has the lowest percentage of both establishments and population, around 5% or less.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) is the primary regulator of the Gold and Silver Mining industry. BLM oversees the enforcement of several mining laws and regulations.
Gold and silver miners are required to comply with Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulations relating to air, water, waste, pollution and land use.
In Nevada, mining companies are required to pay this additional industry-specific tax. The Net Proceeds of Minerals Tax (NPT) is a property tax on mineral value.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Industry assistance level is low and steady.
Competition level is high and steady.

factors_decreased_barrier: Gold and silver mining is very labor intensive, but is much more reliant on capital to purchase equipment and machinery than it is on its workforce.

basis_points.basis_description: The industry has an extremely high level of internal competition.

basis_points.basis_title: Nevada Gold Mines joint venture dominates production
basis_points.basis_description: The Nevada Gold Mines joint venture between Barrick and Newmont is responsible for producing roughly 60.0% of all gold in the United States.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition for new mine properties is nonexistent
basis_points.basis_description: Competition for new mine properties is nonexistent as the major players own and control most higher-grade mines.

basis_points.basis_title: New players compete at lower-grade mines
basis_points.basis_description: New players are left to compete by operating at lower-grade mines which have higher operating costs.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry's high level of concentration is reflected in the fact that nearly a dozen of the largest gold-producing operations in the United States are owned by one company, Nevada Gold Mines.

Large producers have much greater resources necessary to invest in mine exploration and development. The advantages the largest mining companies have makes it increasingly difficult for smaller companies to compete, contributing to industry consolidation.
Industry concentration reflects the scarcity of mineral resource locations in the United States, where the largest and highest volume-producing mines are controlled by a few large companies.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Depreciation represents one of the industry's largest expenses. Depreciation is a major cost for the industry and represents the total investment in capital equipment, plant, mining trucks, other vehicles and other building and production works.

Wages account for 17.7% of revenue in 2023, up from 14.9% in 2018. Wages have grown as a share of revenue over the past five years as mining companies have hired more workers to increase production and capitalize on soaring prices of precious metals.
Purchases include the cost of materials, parts, supplies, contract work, purchased fuels and electricity. Purchase costs account for 25.7% of revenue in 2023, down from 30.9% of revenue in 2018.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Gold and silver mining is very labor intensive
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Gold and silver mining is very labor intensive, but is much more reliant on capital to purchase equipment and machinery than it is on its workforce.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patent technologies
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low, which limits the potential for innovations.
The concentration of technologies is high in this industry. This suggests that industry operators have exposure to potentially unforeseen areas of innovation.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Industry revenue is a function of mine output and world prices. Lower grades and throughput of gold and silver have contributed to a waning supply of precious metals in the United States.
The world prices of gold and silver are extremely responsive to changes in supply and demand and individual mining companies have no room to negotiate since these commodities are fungible.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Soaring gold prices make up for lower production
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Although lower grades and throughput have contributed to a decrease in gold production over the past five years, the yellow metal's price has increased tremendously as investors pile into the safe-haven asset.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: The sliver of silver has been growing
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Although the United States produces much more silver than it does gold, silver accounts for a much smaller share of revenue since it is significantly less valuable.

FAQs.question: Does your company engage in international trade?
FAQs.answer: Imports and exports are minimal in the industry; therefore, the industry does not possess a substantial threat from import penetration.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize heavily, or do you extract a diversified range of resources?
FAQs.answer: Operators primarily mine industry products or mine metals that have produce gold or silver as byproducts. Companies with a more diverse range of products can better withstand price volatility linked to just one commodity.

FAQs.question: Has your company dealt with volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Input prices of steel slightly affect purchase costs for operators in the industry. Rising oil prices may lead to an increase in purchase costs, contributing to below average profit.

FAQs.question: How do you evaluate the profitability of a mining (or quarrying) location?
FAQs.answer: Profitability for mines that have been in operation for a long time has remained steady. Profit tends to move alongside gold and silver prices.

FAQs.question: How is your company using new technology, such as new drilling techniques?
FAQs.answer: Some operators have invested in autonomous machines and processing facilities to reduce labor dependency. Implementing technological advancements, such as drones and new geological surveying methods, can increase efficiency.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Mining companies are experimenting with the use of autonomous machinery in operations which will help contain the need for employees. Human labor is still essential for the mining sector.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted your company's profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: The industry encounters a high level of regulation, with oversight from state governments on virtually all aspects of the mining operation.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: It is critical to follow all health and safety standards in this industry. Mining companies must ensure workers wear the proper equipment and proceed with caution to reduce injury.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare to your competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Average industry profit can improve due to the appreciation of gold and silver prices and due to cost-savings synergies stemming from the combination of mining operations. High transportation costs and raw material expenses can encroach on average industry profit.

FAQs.question: Do you have any big projects on the horizon that will require capital financing?
FAQs.answer: Mining projects require a large-scale capital investment; therefore, operators are in constant need of financing new projects or expanding existing projects.

FAQs.question: Do you have access to high-quality inputs? How do you contend with fluctuations in input prices?
FAQs.answer: Access to large, high-grade reserves is important. A larger deposit generally permits economies of scale and also provides greater flexibility in scheduling output. High-grade reserves are also desirable since their production typically results in lower operating costs.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure its production is sufficient to meet demand? Are you able to quickly adjust your operations if needed?
FAQs.answer: Successful producers have a capacity to read future trends in demand for industry goods and adjust production accordingly. Amid price rises, companies that have been able to ramp up production amid historic precious metal prices have experienced rising revenue and profit.

FAQs.question: How do you monitor changing environmental laws? Have you had any compliance issues in the past?
FAQs.answer: Companies must be able to meet environmental laws and regulations to successfully develop and operate mines. Even after resources are depleted, companies are responsible for land reclamation and may even be found responsible to pay for cleanup if an environmental hazard exists. Industry players that are recognized for safety and reclamation often have more successful operations and are more likely to avoid costly expenses which had previously been overlooked.

FAQs.question: How do you prepare to deal with volatile gold prices? How quickly can you adjust output according to prices? Can you hedge against the potential for gold prices to fall from where they currently stand?
FAQs.answer: As the Gold and Silver Ore Mining industry's highest-grossing product, increases in the price of gold drive revenue growth, while declines in the price of gold hinder revenue prospects.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your sales is derived from silver mining? Do you closely track the price of silver?
FAQs.answer: The world price of silver reflects trends in the international supply and industrial demand for the metal.

FAQs.question: How can you capitalize on increasing investor uncertainty? How do you promote the security of gold and silver investments?
FAQs.answer: Gold has long been regarded as a safe and secure investment. When economic uncertainty rises and investors seek to transfer funds from riskier assets into safer assets, demand for gold increases.
